review.title: Metric Learning Driven Multi-Task Structured Output Optimization for Robust Keypoint Tracking
review.abstract: As an important and challenging problem in computer vision and graphics, keypoint-based object tracking is typically formulated in a spatio-temporal statistical learning framework. However, most existing keypoint trackers are incapable of effectively modeling and balancing the following three aspects in a simultaneous manner: temporal model coherence across frames, spatial model consistency within frames, and discriminative feature construction. To address this issue, we propose a robust keypoint tracker based on spatio-temporal multi-task structured output optimization driven by discriminative metric learning. Consequently, temporal model coherence is characterized by multi-task structured keypoint model learning over several adjacent frames, while spatial model consistency is modeled by solving a geometric verification based structured learning problem. Discriminative feature construction is enabled by metric learning to ensure the intra-class compactness and inter-class separability. Finally, the above three modules are simultaneously optimized in a joint learning scheme. Experimental results have demonstrated the effectiveness of our tracker.

metadata.title: Metric Learning Driven Multi-Task Structured Output Optimization for Robust Keypoint Tracking

sections.heading: 2 Approach
sections.text: Our tracking approach essentially consists of two parts: the learning part and the prediction part. In other words, an object model is first learned through a structured multi-task learning scheme in a discriminatory attribute space (induced by metric learning). Based on the object model we learned, our approach then produces the follow-up results through structured prediction. On the basis of the follow-up results, further training samples for structured learning are collected.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preliminary
sections.text: Let the template image O be presented as a series of keypointsO = {(ui, qi)} N Oi = 1, each keypoint being defined by a location ui and the associated descriptor qi. Similarly, I = {(vj, dj) N Ij = 1 shall denote the input frame with keypoints. Typically, traditional approaches construct the correspondences between the keypoints of the template and the keypoints of the intervention frame. Correspondences will be parameterized by calculating the distances between {qi} N O i = 1 and {dj} N Ij = 1. According to the modeling learning approaches (Hare, Saffari and Torr 2012; Stuckler and Behnke 2012), we will parameterise a model by a weight vector wi for the template keypoint ui to evaluate each correspondence. sections.heading: 2.3 Discriminative Feature Space
sections.text: In order to adapt the keypoint descriptors well to the time-changing tracking situations, we want to learn a mapping function f (d) that maps the original feature space to another discriminatory feature space, in which the semantically similar keypoints are close to each other, while the unequal keypoints are far apart, which can be formulated as a metric learning process. Figure 3 shows an example of such a feature space transformation. Before the mapping procedure the object keypoints and the background keypoints in the original feature space cannot be discriminated against.

referenceMentions.context: 1 Introduction Due to the effectiveness and efficiency in object motion analysis, keypoint-based object tracking (Lucas and Kanade 1981; Santner et al. 2010; Maresca and Petrosino 2013; Nebehay and Pflugfelder 2014) is a popular and powerful tool of video processing, and thus has a wide range of applications such as augmented reality (AR), object retrieval, and video compression.

Following the model learning approaches (Hare, Saffari, and Torr 2012; Stückler and Behnke 2012), we learn a model parameterized by a weight vector wi for the template keypoint ui to score each correspondence.
We model each w as a linear combination of a common model w and an unique part v (Zheng and Ni 2013): w = w + v, k = 1, .

In our approach, the expected transformation ŷ is expressed as ŷ = arg maxy∈Y F (C,y), where F is a compatibility function, scoring all possible transformations generated by using the RANSAC (Fischler and Bolles 1981) method.

Given training samples {(Ct,yt)}t=1 (each Ct is the hypothetical correspondences of the frame It, and yt is the predicted transformation), a structured output maximum margin framework (Taskar, Guestrin, and Koller 2003; Tsochantaridis et al. 2005) is used to learn all the multi-task models, which can be expressed by the following optimization problem:

Implementation Details For keypoint feature extraction, we use FAST keypoint detector (Rosten and Drummond 2006) with 256-bit BRIEF descriptor (Calonder et al. 2010).

metadata.abstractText: As an important and challenging problem in computer vision and graphics, keypoint-based object tracking is typically formulated in a spatio-temporal statistical learning framework. However, most existing keypoint trackers are incapable of effectively modeling and balancing the following three aspects in a simultaneous manner: temporal model coherence across frames, spatial model consistency within frames, and discriminative feature construction. To address this issue, we propose a robust keypoint tracker based on spatio-temporal multi-task structured output optimization driven by discriminative metric learning. Consequently, temporal model coherence is characterized by multi-task structured keypoint model learning over several adjacent frames, while spatial model consistency is modeled by solving a geometric verification based structured learning problem. Discriminative feature construction is enabled by metric learning to ensure the intra-class compactness and inter-class separability. Finally, the above three modules are simultaneously optimized in a joint learning scheme. Experimental results have demonstrated the effectiveness of our tracker.
